11:04 am

PM

Let me share his words tho

PM

BREXIT & the War on Inequality In 2015 London accounted for 28% of all English housing sales despite accounting for
just 1-2% of the total land area. BREXIT is thus far the biggest electoral riposte to our
Age of Inequality. Our secular conclusion is that investors must start to anticipate new
populist policy responses & position for 1. higher levels of gold, volatility & cash, 2.
Main Street assets to outperform Wall Street assets and 3. outperformance of an
uber-barbell strategy that plays to the reality of deflation and the anticipation of more
desperate inflationary policy responses.

11:05 am
PM

The Brexit vote was a shock to Wall Street because an electorate in a country with no
economic or financial crisis voted to dramatically change its political status quo. This
partly reflects the fact that economic recovery in recent years has been a. deflationary
and b. unequal. Wall Street has prospered; Main Street has not (Chart 2). Extreme
monetary stimulus has failed to deliver a knockout blow to Deflation. The global
economy remains stuck in a deflationary expansion of minimal growth & minimal rates.
And electorates are increasingly voting in the developed world against wage deflation,
high unemployment, immigration & inequality. Thus the failed “War on Deflation” is
soon giving way to a “War on Inequality” which could feature the following:

BE

Yeah, the words are silly too. With all due respect.

PM

1. Trade protectionism: this is most bullish for gold & volatility, most bearish for
equities & credit. Trade tariffs, capital & labor market controls, and the constant threat
of a currency war are likely to be very negative for corporate "animal spirits". Investment
and jobs are unlikely to be boosted by protectionism.
2. Regressive taxation/higher minimum wages/regulation for higher bank capital: this
is most bullish for bonds, especially Treasuries & US Munis, at the expense of cyclical
stocks & banks. Higher taxes on rich will likely hurt small business confidence &
entrench the "deflationary expansion”. Minimum wage increases would simply
exacerbate wage deflation as companies replace humans with robots to keep
margins/profits high (Chart 3). Higher capital in the banking system, perhaps in lieu of
Fed rate hikes, is unlikely to spur credit expansion.

11:05 am
PM

3. New Deal fiscal stimulus financed by helicopter money: this is most bullish for risk
assets, but would most likely be in reaction to a recession and bear market (sadly
options 1 & 2 are more politically viable). "Helicopter money” (central bank printing) to
directly finance tax cuts for the poor, infrastructure spending (can you think of a better
time for infrastructure spending with rates so low, commodity prices so low and private
equity flush with cash?) and/or the introduction of "living wages" are policies that have
the best chance of boosting both growth & inflation expectations over the next 2 years.
Fiscal stimulus is the best route to jump-start the zombification of aggregate global
demand. Japan’s “Takahashi Economic Policy” of 1932-36 is the best example of
successful fiscal expenditures backed by deficit financing with the central bank’s credit.
And Japan once again is the most likely location for this next chapter of policy easing
(driven by excessive yen strength).

PM

Bond yields will be the barometer of Regime Change. Policy makers must induce a
"good" rise in bond yields via fiscal policy. But their response won't happen overnight. In
the meantime, investors should adopt the following 3 strategies:
1. Investors should continue looking for opportunities to add to their positions in gold
and volatility; we would expect cash levels to remain high. Gold, vol & cash remain our
favored positions to play the "Twilight Zone" of the QE-led bull market in risk assets.
2. Investors should be long Main St plays (e.g. regional banks & mass retailers), and
short Wall St plays (e.g. broker/dealers & luxury retail). Policy makers will aim to
maximize the spending power of the poor and minimize the spending power of the rich.
3. Investors should be long an “uber-barbell” of high-growth/high-quality stocks
(F.A.N.G., global Best-of-Breed stocks and "yield plays") and underowned inflation assets
(commodities, TIPS, EM and the UK). The high-growth/high-quality tail of this barbell
reflects the fact that deflation and the collapse in all global rates to zero will exacerbate
the rich valuations in these sectors. The more controversial belief in "inflation assets"
reflects the distressed valuations that appear in these assets and the anticipation that
policy will ultimately have to reverse the slump in inflation expectations. Two good
hunting grounds for the secular contrarian: UK stocks...currently at 40-year lows versus
Developed Markets (Chart 4); commodities...where the rolling return is currently at 80-
year lows (Chart 5).

PM

Done with that

11:06 am
PM

On the pure UK politics of the matter

PM

Malcolm Barr of JPM always a good read on such stuff

PM

The politics of the here and now. UK politics is in unprecedented flux at this point. The most important process to watch is that around the Conservative leadership. The 1922 Committee (of which Graham Brady is the Chair) will set out the timescale. Theresa May and Boris Johnson will likely be the key contenders, and the elements of their pitch to MPs and party members will come the closest to setting out an agenda for the Brexit process that we will have at this point. Johnson’s piece in the Daily Telegraph today does a lot of “one nation” positioning but beyond that offers little insight. What is going on on the Labour side is less important for the near term agenda. The issue is that the party membership appears minded to support leadership with a more clearly defined left-wing political agenda. And whether or not Mr Corbyn is the leader, there are lingering questions about whether the party has lost its connection with many working class voters.

11:07 am
PM

On general elections and a second referendum. Amid the current vacuum of leadership, there is much discussion of the need for new mandates and possible reconsideration of the referendum decision. The number of signatories to a petition calling for a second referendum has reached 3.6mn and is still rising (note this petition can only force a Parliamentary debate on the issue, and is primarily useful as a barometer of strength of feeling more than anything else). In our view, however, whoever takes over as Conservative Party leader and hence PM will have the whip hand in shaping this agenda.
That future PM is only likely to consider holding a general election before 2020 (a) if they see advantage in doing so, or (b) if that is forced on them by rebellion among their own MPs. On the first of these, the future PM will be aware of the likelihood that a new election could become a pseudo referendum on the EU issue, which may work against outcomes they would like. On the second, the fact that the Conservative party has a relatively small (17 seat) majority at this stage makes it is possible that a group of pro-EU Conservative MPs frustrates the new PM and seeks to prevent exit (for example, by voting against a motion to submit the article 50 request). However, we are not aware of any Conservative MPs that have suggested that they will do so thus far, and they will be under enormous pressure from both the parliamentary party and local Conservative associations to fall into line.

PM

As for a second referendum on EU membership, our sense is that there is only a small likelihood of this occurring. The incoming PM may hint that a future referendum on the terms of an exit could occur, which means it would be years away, by which time an enormous amount of work on establishing the exit would have been done. In the early phase of the next PM’s term, they will have a referendum result and a mandate from the Conservative party to lean on, and this is likely to establish the direction of travel as towards making the EU exit a reality, rather than reconsidering the decision at this point.

PM

On Article 50 and the process. Although the rest of the region can attempt to exert pressure on the UK to formally make the “article 50” request to withdraw from the EU, it is ultimately the UK’s decision. The most effective form of such pressure is simply to refuse to begin substantive discussions on the exit until the Article 50 request has been made. Leave campaigners have suggested there needs to be informal talks before the Article 50 request is made – our best guess is that these talks will occur but will not go beyond offering a sketch of the multi-year process that is to follow. There is a chance of a protracted stand off as the UK demands talks begin without the “two year” clock ticking, while the EU refuses. Our best guess, however, is that the Article 50 request will be made by the early part of next year at the latest, and most likely before the end of this year. Given the likelihood that uncertainty will be weighing on UK growth, the pressure to be making progress to a resolution of this issue is likely to force the UK’s hand.

11:26 am
BE

SocGen incoming on the sector, first.

BE

EPS estimates down by 10-20%
In this note we cut our 2018 adjusted EPS forecasts by
15-20% for the UK domestic banks and 10% (in US$ terms) for HSBC. We incorporate
impacts from the likely slowdown in the economy, which will affect both revenues (we
factor in rate cuts) and higher credit costs.

BE

Longer-term business model changes
Key for the banks will be the discussion between
the UK and EU about banks’ access to European markets, particularly important for those
with investment banking operations. Will UK-based banks be allowed to use the passport
system? Will there be a workaround? Second, the Scottish National Party has already said
that a second independence referendum is ‘on the table’, albeit the economics of this are
more difficult with $50 oil.

11:27 am
BE

Sector recommendation & catalysts
The UK remains one of our preferred regions within
European banks. Yes, the UK is the epicentre of the Brexit gyrations, but Brexit is a major
issue for the rest of Europe. UK banks are reasonably well capitalised and have some
decent businesses and are better able to deal with turbulence than banks in some other
areas. Investment banks and Spanish banks remain some of our least preferred banks.

BE

Main stock picks
Within the UK, we retain our preference for Lloyds, thanks to strong
pre-provision profitability. We keep a Buy on Barclays (higher quality UK business and non-
sterling revenues) and HSBC (we still expect a maintained dividend, although it’s getting
tighter). Standard Chartered remains Hold and RBS moved to Sell as mentioned above.

BE

And ..........

11:27 am
BE

Investment cases in brief
Lloyds Banking Group (Buy, target price 70p, prior 98p)
Lloyds is the largest UK retail and commercial bank and has little non-UK activities. It will
therefore feel any deterioration in the UK economy. But, because of its focus on high-return
UK retail and lack of low-return investment banking, it is very capital generative. We have
lowered our dividend forecasts to pay for higher impairments, but nonetheless we still see the
bank on a yield of 8%. Lloyds is the biggest mortgage lender in the UK, but we note that it has
been shrinking London balances over the past couple of years. On the other hand, the car
finance book has doubled from £5bn to £10bn over the past couple of years, so this will be
the area to watch if the UK economy looks very tough.
Barclays (Buy, target price 185p, prior 245p)
Barclays has some attractive retail and commercial operations. Its loan origination standards
are typically somewhat better than other UK banks, and so this side of the business should
fare better. In addition, only 50% of its revenues are from the UK, so weaker sterling should
help the bottom line (and the sterling value of the for-sale Africa business is higher). The
impact of Brexit on the investment bank is less clear. On the one hand, near-term revenues
will likely benefit from the higher volatility and trading volumes. On the other, it could suffer
from withdrawal of the passport system unless a workaround is found. The shares will likely
be sensitive to newsflow on this issue, albeit it will likely not actually affect the numbers for
some years yet.
HSBC (Buy, target price 510p, prior 630p)
HSBC benefits from having most of the group outside of the UK. Our EPS cut of 10% reflects
downgrades to the UK business, amplified by the fact that HSBC reports in US dollars. Given
that it also declares a dollar dividend, this makes the chance of a dividend cut more likely, but
we still think the more likely outcome is to maintain it. Although HSBC is paying a higher-than-
optimal dividend in our view, the capital base is strong, and should be 12.5% core tier 1 ratio
when the Brazil deal closes later this month. We do not think that Brexit would cause any
major business model changes given its very global profile.
RBS (Sell, target price 200p; prior Hold, 260p)
RBS’s destination (to be a UK-focused retail and commercial bank) is attractive. But for the
moment, it has challenges, namely a large likely settlement from the DoJ regarding US RMBS
and a difficult CIB restructuring. We also note that RBS has been growing fastest of the large
banks in London mortgages and its commercial real estate book remains higher risk than
elsewhere. On the plus side, the consumer credit exposure has been shrinking, so we would
expect less sensitivity to a downturn in this area. Given the lower profitability, we think that it
has less scope to absorb a more difficult environment, so we downgrade to Sell.
Standard Chartered (Hold, target price 575p)
We think that Brexit changes very little for Standard Chartered given that the majority of its
business is in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. New management has made considerable
progress on the balance sheet, boosting the core tier 1 ratio to 13.1% and cutting commodity
exposures down to US$37bn. But revenues are very difficult, down by 21% yoy in Q1, even if
we strip out noisy items. Our fear is that this signifies franchise damage. It is also worth noting
that Standard Chartered’s share price has shown an r-squared value of 90% with the oil price
over the past five years.

BE

(Sterling selling off again. $1.32 ......)

BE

And Jefferies. Same theme. Similar conclusions.

11:28 am
BE

The UK's vote to leave the EU will drive tectonic plate shifts in European bank
investing. We move to a slow growth/modestly recessionary scenario for the
UK banks. '16-18E earnings fall 17%, 46% and 72% for LLOY, RBS and BARC
respectively. LLOY remains BUY - though capital return prospects are likely
diminished and PT falls to 68p; RBS is downgraded to Hold (227p price target)
and BARC is rated Underperform (115p price target).
Tectonic plate shifts. Against a backdrop characterised by interest rates at their lowest
in 100 years and unemployment at its lowest in 35 years, the UK electorate has upturned
decades and potentially (if Scotland is successful with a second referendum) centuries of
agreements that have supported social blocs and created several decades of relative stability.
There is no return to Wednesday 22 June 2016 and we must re-assess risk/reward across
the sector.

BE

Trading the second derivative first? Whilst we take a blunt initial stab at the first
derivative impacts on UK bank earnings & valuations as a result of the referendum, the
second order impacts are potentially more powerful. In our opinion, such risks are likely to
be greater for Eurozone banks given potential domino effects of Brexit in those countries
with relatively weaker capitalised & funded banks. As investors consider incremental central
bank action, geo-political risks and, perhaps, the return of capital controls, they are likely to
scrutinise franchise indicators such as leverage ratios and loan/deposit ratios.
First derivative effects. We cut 2016-2018 earnings estimates by 17%, 46% and 72% for
LLOY, RBS, and BARC respectively. The decline in earnings reflects a slow growth growth
scenario in the UK characterised by lower loan growth, higher impairments and increased
RWA density. Further, for LLOY and RBS, we model £1bn of restructuring charges associated
with separating their Scottish entities (worth 2p and 5p/share respectively).
Valuation & recommendation changes. Despite moving our price target to 68p
(from 108p) we maintain LLOY at BUY. In a separate note, we have downgraded BARC to
Underperform with a 115p price target. In the present note, we downgrade RBS to HOLD
given a 227p price target. We use an ROTE/Ke methodology in which Ke rises 100bps for
each bank as a result of the referendum result. Risks to the downside would be a more severe
recession scenario, macro shocks and major changes to UK investment flows. Upside risks
to our estimates and valuation could emerge if we have been too pessimistic in our earnings
and risk weighted asset density assumptions - in this instance, our EPS, DPS estimates could
rise, driving higher valuation.
Sector positioning. As a team, we maintain BUY ratings on Danske, Natixis, SEB, LLOY
and Credit Agricole. STAN, BARC, DNB are rated Underperform. Nordea, Swedbank, Svenska
Handelsbanken and RBS are Hold rated.

BE

As the dust settles on the momentous and unprecedented decision of the UK
electorate to leave the European Union, we have updated our thoughts on the
UK banking sector.
Our base case is that there will be further monetary easing (negative for NIMs),
lower loan growth, that loan losses will trend upwards, and dividends capital
return is at greater risk likely to be pushed back. We have also added 1% to
the equity risk premium Cost of Equity, and see heightened probability of
management change, particularly at Lloyds. On the other hand, we think Brexit
means an even greater likelihood that Basel 4 is watered down for UK banks.
Whilst we have included higher loan losses, our forecasts do not assume a
recession financial crisis. In fact, UK banks are in a far better position in 2016
to withstand a downturn today than in 2008: capital levels and quality is
higher, and key exposures (such as Ireland / CRE) are lower.

11:32 am
BE

However, one thing is clear: political and economic uncertainty is here to stay,
and we expect the coming weeks and month will see significant volatility in
the share prices of UK financials and those with UK operations. The political
path from here is not clear, and even in the time of writing this report on
Sunday there have been further political developments (resignations of the
opposition cabinet, conflicting comments on when Article 50 may be triggered,
suggestions that the Scottish parliament may block UK’s exit from the EU).
Each of these could see shares swing positively or negatively.

BE

We have updated forecasts, Target Prices and recommendations to best reflect
our view of the current situation. Our 2016 forecasts are largely unchanged –
Brexit has greater implications for 2017/18 and beyond. However, we
acknowledge that in these volatile circumstances it is most useful for investors
to look at relevant positioning and sensitivities. This note includes key
sensitivities to credit risk on mortgage, real estate and consumer credit losses
for UK banks within the context of history. In terms of positioning we prefer
Lloyds (Buy) of the domestics and HSBC (Hold) of the international UK banks:

BE

Of the UK domestics our ranking of preference is Lloyds (Buy TP 63p). We
think this is relatively oversold given that real estate credit exposures are
significantly improved vs 2008, deposit costs have further to fall (should
support margins in near term) and despite cutting the dividend, we still
have a
cash dividend higher than other UK domestics). This is
followed by Barclays (Hold TP 160p), RBS (Hold TP 200p, W&G disposal
likely delayed further along with capital distributions, growth likely to
slow), and finally Aldermore (Hold TP 170p, market sentiment unlikely to
be positive in coming weeks / months). As a pair, we would choose Lloyds
vs. RBS given that the former has nearer term dividend support and
stronger earnings power.

11:32 am
BE

For the UK international Banks (HSBC and Standard Chartered), although
there is an immediate FX translation impact of a weaker GBP (both report
in USD), a bigger concern is from the potential revenue drag into 2017 &
beyond. Negative operating leverage caused by weak revenue trends has
been a key reason of earnings downgrades at both groups and Brexit looks
likely to have pushed an inflection point further into the future. We remain
cautious on both names given their pan-regional business models. We
provide more details on HSBC’s geographic capital allocation which
highlights that the Asian operations arguably represent c70% of Group
value consuming just a third of its capital. Implicitly the rest of the group
(including the UK franchise) may already be trading on just 0.3-0.4x book.
Of the two we prefer HSBC (Hold, 470p TP) vs Standard Chartered (Sell,
480p TP) as a sensible pair to avoid £/$ volatility.

BE

(@BornCynic: I have! A couple of weeks ago! Dreamland is ......... curious. As is the rest of it.)

11:43 am
BE

Then we have the catch-all Brexit warning, which may as well become boilerplate on every RNS from hereon in.

BE

Here, via Barclays, is what's happening to forecasts.

BE

Q3 (June quarter): £28m downgrade. easyJet highlights an “extremely challenging” operating environment in May/June, including French ATC strikes, Gatwick congestion, and severe weather. Yields have also been weaker than expected, with the company citing the Egyptair tragedy in late May, and the effect of disruption on close-in bookings, impacting revenue per seat (RPS) by ~1.6ppt. Therefore, RPS in Q3 is now expected to be -8.6%, vs prior -7%. We believe load factors in June have been relatively stable, with the damage being felt on ticket prices.

11:43 am
BE

Peak summer (Q4) trading uncertainty: £30m+ impact. easyJet is now guiding for H2 RPS to be down mid single digit (prior guide low to mid single digit), which would imply Q4 is at least -2.5% (prior guide had implied Q4 flattish to slightly down). We believe forward booking volumes are similar to last year, but there is still a lot of revenue to sell in the critical peak summer months and the UK referendum outcome could result in subdued consumer activity. easyJet is heavily exposed to UK leisure, especially in peak summer, and the weakening sterling, as well as uncertainty around mortgages, jobs, etc, could well weigh on demand. Prior to the UK referendum, we believe shorthaul travel had been booking well for the summer, but the final RPS outcome is heavily dependent on close-in bookings and the next two months will be crucial. The key risk is that some of easyJet’s competitors respond to demand weakness with promotional activity.

BE

egulatory uncertainty likely to cast a shadow, but liberal agreements
with the UK in the EU's interest: While we expect market concern
regarding the impact of the UK's exit from EU Open Skies to weigh on EZJ
in particular, we see the prospect of the UK joining the European Common
Aviation Area (which includes Norway, Iceland and the Balkan states),
which would preserve the ability for UK airlines to fly intra-EU routes. We
do not expect any impediments to UK-EU air service agreements given our
view that liberal air service agreements between the UK and EU would be
of mutual benefit.

BE

Elevated uncertainty but structural winners should represent
investment opportunities when the dust settles – RYA most
defensive: We acknowledge elevated levels of uncertainty surrounding UK
leisure and corporate demand prospects. However, we continue to see the
outlook for IAG, RYA and EZJ (representing the top layer of quality in the
sector) as superior to competitors Air France KLM and Lufthansa (each
Underperform rated). We make three key points that will be crucial to
investment case developments from here (i) while we model cumulative
constant currency pricing declines of 8%-10% at IAG-EZJ in FY16E-FY17E
and fare declines of 15% at RYA in FY17E-FY18E, we model ROIC of
15%-27% ROIC over calendar 2017-2018 for the group – we consider
these returns prospects compelling despite uncertainty, (ii) our lowered
estimates still produce average 3Y FCF yields of 6% at RYA, 10% at IAG
and 3% at EZJ, validating sustainability to an extent, (iii) as with historical
demand shocks, LCCs are likely to react to weaker demand with lower
pricing to ensure continued market share gains – this is likely to further
concentrate the UK and European air travel markets over time, and further
Ryanair's ambitions to build out its pan-European position in particular.

BE

First half and full year profits are set to be significantly lower
than the prior year given the uncertainty in the lead up to and in
the aftermath of the EU referendum vote. We believe FY2016
PBT could halve compared to our current forecasts. Liquidity in
the London property market will return but we continue to
believe that Foxtons is not best placed to capture the upside
given its high commission rates. Market share growth will remain
a challenge. Our new target price is 100p.

BE

Trading update. After a decent first quarter when trading was boosted by a rush
of transactions to beat the stamp duty changes, uncertainty has weighed on
activity since. Friday’s referendum result has amplified this uncertainty and
profits for H1 and FY will be significantly below prior year levels. For H1,
revenues will be slightly below the prior year at c£70m, but the higher costs from
the larger branch network will see the EBITDA margin decline to c20% from
29% in H1 2015. This implies H1 EBITDA of c£13m-14m (H1 2015: £20.5m).
Transactions outlook tough. The group’s pipeline for transactions in Q2 had
declined due to the pull forward of activity to beat the stamp change. While
there has been little time to assess how many people may pull out of transactions,
it is likely to have some impact and transaction activity will be subdued for at
least the remainder of this year. In the meantime, the world of estate agency is
changing with lower priced players gaining share. As and when the London
market rebounds, Foxtons’ commission rate of 2.5% on sales will be even more of
an outlier, in our view.
Lettings challenging. Lettings provides the group with a relatively stable
income stream, however, organic growth of the lettings book has been slow as
tenants are typically staying in properties for longer and churn between lettings
agents has slowed. We expect a modest (1-2%) reduction in lettings revenues for
the full year, which implies a material decline in market share given the growth in
the branch network.
Forecasts and valuation. We are yet to finalise our forecasts, however, the weak
outlook for transactions could see second half transaction revenues 30-40% lower
than the prior year. If we take the mid point of this (35%), combined with the
slight fall in lettings stated above, group revenues for the full year would be
£132m (our current forecast is £159m). At a c20% EBITDA margin, this implies
EBITDA of £26m (our current forecast is £46m) and PBT of c£21m (our current
forecast is £42.6m). The dividend, which is covered c1x by earnings will also be
under similar pressure to our PBT forecasts. While 2016 may well be trough
earnings, given the uncertainty around the London market and competitive
headwinds we cannot justify applying any more than a 15-16x PE ratio to this
year’s earnings. If the group generates £21m of PBT in FY2016 (c6.1p EPS), a
16x PE implies a c100p target price. We maintain our reduce recommendation.

11:55 am
BE

Foxtons first half trading update highlights the extent of the Q2 slowdown in
London residential transactions, in response to the uncertainty caused by Brexit
and stamp duty changes. We expect a material yoy reduction in both half and
full-year profits, which will also have a corresponding impact on dividends. We
continue to believe that Foxtons model will gain market share and generate
significant cash, but the short to medium term is highly difficult to predict.

BE

● The group has reported that as a result of the uncertainty surrounding the referendum
and the impact of the stamp duty surcharge on second homes, the group has witnessed
a very difficult Q2 in sales volumes. As a result of these reduced volumes, alongside
the increase in costs relating to the branch roll out strategy (the group has 7 more
branches in-situ yoy), first half revenue is expected to be below 2015 and the EBITDA
margin is c.10% percentage points lower. We estimate this equates to c.£12m-14m H1
EBITDA (H1 2015 £20.5m) and given the group had a strong Q1, it implies the second
quarter was close to break even.
● Clearly with the UK voting to leave the EU we would expect uncertainty to persist
through the second half, with the biggest unknown being how will overseas investors
respond to the sharp fall in Sterling. Whilst Foxtons can withstand a slowdown, given
the strength of its balance sheet and the flexibility of its cost base, the heightened
level of uncertainty in the short to medium term is likely to weigh heavily on the shares
this morning. Based on the first half result and considering the added uncertainty of
Brexit, we think an outcome of c.£30m of EBITDA in 2016 feels possible, down from
our previous expectation of £47m. We would expect dividends to reduce in line with
profits. Clearly this forecast depends on the extent of on-going uncertainty, but it should
be considered that Q3 is usually supported by high lettings volumes, which should
provide some support.
● In our view, with uncertainty set to continue at least in the short term, it will raise
questions over Foxtons branch expansion strategy and the associated increase in
underlying costs. Whilst this strategy is undoubtedly depressing profits in the short
term, we think it is the right strategy, as it is broadening the group's geographic profile
across Greater London which should help mitigate the volatilities of Central London
and position the group to the better performing outer zones.
